title: 115_hr3629
content:
The "Payroll Fraud Prevention Act of 2017" is the short title of this Act. It classifies employees and non-employees. The Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 has been amended to define 'Non-employee' as an individual engaged for labor or services but not an employee. A 'Covered individual' includes employees and non-employees engaged for labor or services by an employer or person required to file an information return. The Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 has been amended to classify individuals engaged for labor or services through entities like trusts, estates, partnerships, etc., as non-employees if certain conditions are met. This includes ownership interest in the entity, the entity being necessary for the provision of labor or services, and the requirement for the person to file an information return for the entity. The Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 has been amended to require accurate classification of individuals as employees or non-employees by employers. Every person subject to the Act must provide a notice to each employee and maintain a copy of it. The Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 has been amended to require accurate classification of individuals as employees or non-employees by employers. A notice must be provided to each covered individual, including new employees and non-employees, within 6 months of the Payroll Fraud Prevention Act of 2017 enactment. Additionally, the notice must be given to individuals upon a change in their status. The notice required under the Fair Labor Standards Act amendment must inform covered individuals of their classification as an employee or non-employee, direct them to the Department of Labor website for more information on legal rights, and provide contact information for the local Department of Labor office. The notice required under the Fair Labor Standards Act amendment must include the address and telephone number of the local Department of Labor office. It should also inform non-employee individuals about their rights and provide a statement to contact the U.S. Department of Labor if they suspect misclassification. The Fair Labor Standards Act amendment presumes a covered individual is an employee if not provided with notice within the required time. The presumption can only be rebutted with clear and convincing evidence. Additionally, the Act prohibits discrimination against covered individuals for certain actions. The Fair Labor Standards Act prohibits discrimination against covered individuals for certain actions, including opposing practices related to the Act, testifying in related proceedings, or serving on an industry committee. The Fair Labor Standards Act prohibits discrimination against covered individuals for certain actions, including opposing practices related to the Act, testifying in related proceedings, or serving on an industry committee. Amendments have been made to include penalties for misclassification, recordkeeping, and notice violations. The Fair Labor Standards Act prohibits discrimination against covered individuals for certain actions, including opposing practices related to the Act, testifying in related proceedings, or serving on an industry committee. Amendments have been made to include penalties for misclassification, recordkeeping, and notice violations. Liquidated damages are doubled for violations of specific sections with respect to employees. The Fair Labor Standards Act now includes penalties for violations of specific sections such as section 6, 7, 11(c), or 15(a)(6), with civil penalties ranging from $1,100 to $5,000 for each employee affected by the violation. The Secretary of Labor will create a webpage summarizing employee rights under the Fair Labor Standards Act within 180 days of the Act's enactment. Additionally, there will be measures to address misclassification of employees for unemployment compensation purposes. The Social Security Act is amended to include auditing procedures to identify non-compliant employers and establish penalties for misclassifying employees or paying unreported wages. Quarterly reports on these procedures must be submitted to the Secretary of Labor. The Secretary of Labor will review auditing programs. The Secretary of Labor will review auditing programs to measure States' effectiveness in identifying underreported wages and underpayment of unemployment compensation. The amendments made by subsection (a) will take effect 12 months after enactment, with exceptions for states needing legislative changes for compliance. The amendments made by subsection (a) will not apply to a State until the later of the day after the close of the first regular session of the legislature or 12 months after the date of enactment of the Act. The term "State" is defined as per section 3306(j) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. SEC. 5. DEPARTMENT OF LABOR COORDINATION, REFERRAL, AND REGULATIONS.

Any office, administration, or division of the Department of Labor obtaining information on misclassification under the Fair Labor Standards Act must report to the Wage and Hour Division. The Division may further report to the Internal Revenue Service. The Secretary of Labor will create regulations for this Act and its amendments.

SEC. 6. TARGETED AUDITS. SEC. 6. TARGETED AUDITS. Audits of employers under the Fair Labor Standards Act will target industries with frequent misclassification of employees as non-employees, as determined by the Secretary of Labor.
